break-your-app-before-someone-else-does.name: Break your app before someone else does
break-your-app-before-someone-else-does.description: Welcoming everyone to Windy City DevCon and thanking our sponsors.

accessibility-at-scale.name: Accessibility @ Scale
accessibility-at-scale.description: This presentation will provide an overview of the platform including a few demos of key products within GCP.

i-like-the-way-you-move.name: I Like The Way You Move
i-like-the-way-you-move.description:
Google Cardboard has been around since Google I/O 2014. It is by far the most affordable, and possibly most clever VR viewer out there today. To develop for Google Cardboard, the popular 3d game engine, Unity can be used. 

This presentation will cover the  basics of developing in Unity for Google Cardboard including:
• What is Unity and how to develop 3d apps using it.
• How to develop for Google Cardboard in a Unity project.
• Best practices for developing for Google Cardboard.

retrofitting-retrofit.name: Retrofitting Retrofit
retrofitting-retrofit.description: Hands on Firebase demo and talk

mixed-reality-for-social-good.name: Mixed Reality for Social Good
mixed-reality-for-social-good.description: A deep dive into the world of animation in Material Design. We'll cover what Material Design is, how natural motion plays a role in its principles and how to create meaningful animations that exhibit the essence of Material Design strives for.

contextualize-apps-with-nearby-awareness.name: Contextualize Apps with Nearby + Awareness
contextualize-apps-with-nearby-awareness.description: So you want to start a DevOps revolution. Great...where do you start? Going from manual deployments to a fully automated delivery pipeline has brought many changes; both technical and cultural. In this talk, we will cover "the five phases of DevOps" we found on our journey at Gogo. Finally, we will wrap up the talk with how you too can start your own DevOps revolution including some tool demos and examples.

write-less-code-and-get-more-done.name: Write Less Code and Get More Done: Multiplying Your Impact Through Mentorship
write-less-code-and-get-more-done.description: Have you seen Cloud Spin? It's a demo that Google Cloud Developer Advocates (Ray Tsang, Bret McGowen, and Francesc Campoy) developed for the Google Cloud Platform Next event series. The demo, consists of 19 Nexus 6 cameras that were placed around a half-circle pointing inwards to take a picture of the subject at the same moment in time, to create a 180 degree animated GIF - see them at @googlecloudspin twitter! But wait, the Android cameras introduces some unknown delays when taking a photo - how did we make all the cameras take pictures at the same time? What did we use to process and stitch the photos together? And most importantly, how did we pull it off in a matter of 3 weeks? Join this session to learn more about what we did behind the scenes, and how we leveraged open source technology, Google Cloud Platform, and Firebase to help us develop the demo rapidly.

from-interactions-to-insights.name: From Interactions To Insights: Data-Driven Development with Firebase Analytics
from-interactions-to-insights.description: The Firebase Database lets you synchronize data between clients in real time, which is perfect for building multi-player games. In this talk I will describe a collaborative web-based sci-fi game I built using Firebase, what I learned along the way and how it made me a better dad.

websocket-to-me.name: WebSocket to Me!
websocket-to-me.description: As developers, you interact with Android system services every day. They expose a host of platform features to applications, but what do you really know about them? In this talk, we will examine the system service architecture that connects applications to device hardware. You will gain a deeper understanding of core platform technologies such as Binder IPC and AIDL, which you can use to tune how your applications interact with the platform.

just-android-things.name: Just Android Things...
just-android-things.description:
Starting a new Android app is always exciting: you have the opportunity to create an awesome app from zero... but it is also a lot of responsibility! Any step in the wrong direction might turn your new app into a disaster. 
You need the right people on your team, you need the right technology and you need the proper setup.
Sounds easy, uh? Well... it's not! Many apps did not survive even this first step. Let me help you to identify the key elements to help your Android team succeed.

whats-new-in-firebase.name: What's new in Firebase
whats-new-in-firebase.description:
What’s the deal with Kotlin? Why would you want to learn a new programming language to write Android apps - isn’t Java good enough? This talk is for those unacquainted with Kotlin, and might teach those who are familiar some new tricks.

This talk will cover:
- Why Kotlin is a good choice for Android Developers
- How to solve problems in more expressive ways with Kotlin’s language features
- Some interesting Kotlin libraries and tools

where-i-find-stairs-tango.name: Where I find stairs, Tango?
where-i-find-stairs-tango.description:
Join Shan Motlani and Valerie Scarlata will introduce you to Angular 2 and lead you through a codelab with Angular 2 and Firebase
We'll go over...
- What has changed in Angular 2 vs. Angular 1.x
- Using TypeScript to code faster and safer
- The building blocks of Angular 2 Apps - Components, Services and Directives
Then we will walk you through the development flow of an Angular 2 app by building one that integrates Firebase.

rxjava-2-for-the-rest-of-us.name: RxJava 2 for the Rest of Us

2017-04-20.name: Break your app before someone else does
2017-04-20.description: Welcoming everyone to Windy City DevCon and thanking our sponsors.

2017-04-21.name: RxJava 2 for the Rest of Us

mallison.bio:
Mark Allison is a GDE for Android and software engineer with over 30 years' experience. He is passionate about providing the user with the best possible experience. He has developed both server and client side, most commonly Android on the client side, but with also for iOS, HTML5, Symbian, and J2ME. Mark writes a technical blog (http://blog.stylingandroid.com) which focuses on Android UI/UX topics, but often covers more general Android development techniques. 

When not being geeky, Mark likes to unwind by hurling abuse at football referees, specifically those who are unkind to his beloved Watford FC with whom he holds a season ticket. He also has a deep love of the chilli pepper and consumes spicy food (his favourite being Indian) at every opportunity! Mark is happily married with a grown up step-daughter, and lives in Hertfordshire, UK.
mallison.name: Mark Allison

abaotic.bio: During college I got involved in e-learning projects where I developed in Java, and ended up in love with it. After graduation I got a job at Infinum as an Android developer, and have been working there ever since. By the end of 2014. I switched from various projects in the telecommunication, medical and travel industry to mobile banking, where I became the Technical Manager of Mobile Banking in early 2016. My responsibilities include researching new technology and advancements in security, making sure new practices are implemented and generally pushing things forward in the right direction.
abaotic.name: Ana Baotić

rbhalla.bio: I'm a Google Expert for Design and a Partner at Uncommon, one of the leading design studios in India.
rbhalla.name: Raveesh Bhalla

pbreault.bio: Philippe is a software engineer at American Express and has been passionate about android since 2010.He worked on a wide variety of Android apps for banks, newspapers, startups, television providers and more.He is a GDE (Google Developer Expert), one of founding organizers of droidcon Montréal and the author of the adb idea plugin for Android studio.
pbreault.name: Philippe Breault

ecaron-petit-pas.bio:
Etienne is a software developer who’s worked on all tiers (server, web, mobile and embedded) of large scale software platforms. He is now a Mobile Dev Lead for Shopify, and is part of Google's Developer Expert program. 

Etienne got his start in programming in the mid-'80s obsessing over C64 demos, and went on to organize the NAID 95/96 demoparties. 3D animation, procedural content generation and VR are some of his hobbies, and he loves to introduce other developers to this fascinating field. He also regularly volunteers his time towards mentoring startups, developers and students in the mobile space. As part of the Montreal Android GDG, he organises meet-ups, hackathons, and gives regular talks on Android and VR-related subjects.

Previously, Etienne worked on projects ranging from high-availability stock trading software platforms, all the way to large scale municipal bike sharing systems (London’s cycle Hire amongst others). He lives in Montreal with his wife and daughter, and speaks French and English fluently.
ecaron-petit-pas.name: Etienne Caron-Petit-Pas

cchang.bio: I'm currently working on the Android team on June Oven, building the first truly smart oven to help anybody cook! Previously I worked at VSCO, helping build and support the Android app for over 5 million users. I've taught a few Android classes through organizations such as Women Who Code and also AP Computer Science for high school students.
cchang.name: Caren Chang

hdao.bio:
Huyen Tue Dao is an Android developer and Google Developer Expert, currently working on the Android team at Trello.

Huyen is co-creator of the "Android Dialogs" YouTube channel which features interviews with people in the Android community.

She lives in Denver, CO though is often found in the DC Metro area. When she is not up late programming, she is often found up late gaming (video, board, card, anything).
hdao.name: Huyen Tue Dao

bduff.bio: Brian Duff cofounded and leads the Nearby team at Google. He's been on the Android team for the last four years, and hacking on Java in various forms since 1998. As well as being crazily into proximity and Android, Brian loves guitar, looking after his 3 and 4 year old, and singing his geeky heart out.
bduff.name: Brian Duff

vgonda.bio: Victoria is a software developer at Collective Idea, building mobile and web applications. She is passionate about using technology to help better the lives of individuals. Studying both Computer Science and Dance in college, she now enjoys digging into dance technology, and keeping up with dance classes in her spare time.
vgonda.name: Victoria Gonda

cguzman.bio: Originally a ruby on rails developer, Chris made the jump into Android a year ago. He started his dev career 2 years ago after teaching himself to code. Chris loves helping others learn and leads intro to code classes as wells as co-organizes the Baltimore Hackathon.
cguzman.name: Chris Guzman

jhoford.bio: John works on Android Studio and ConstraintLayout at Google. He has worked previously on RenderScript, Vector Drawables, computed shadows and photo editor filters. Prior to joining Google, John was a principal engineer at GE Healthcare working on their image processing applications framework.
jhoford.name: John Hoford

akelly.bio: Andrew is a freelance Android Developer based in Sydney Australia. He is also a Google Developer Expert for Android and is one of the organisers of the Sydney Google Developer Group. When he's not coding Andrew is an avid film watcher.
akelly.name: Andrew Kelly

clee.bio: Christina is a Android developer at Pinterest. After launching the first version of the Pinterest video player on Android, she now works on a special initiatives team doing rapid prototyping for research and validation purposes.
clee.name: Christina Lee

jmaltz.bio: I'm an Android engineering building applications at as part of the diner growth team at Yelp Eat24.  Before that, I worked on Yelp's Android application as part of their diner growth team.  When I'm not having dreams  of little green robots, you can find me anxiously waiting for the next batch of interns so that I get to help more people become great developers.
jmaltz.name: Jonathan Maltz

nnarasimhan.bio:
Independent developer and solutions architect targeting the Mobile Web. Completed a PhD in Computer Eng., and worked at Motorola Research on mobile and ubiquitous computing solutions spanning automotive, television, smartphone and wearable platforms for 12 years. Currently work with early stage startups to build cross-platform mobile web product for consumers. 

Organize GDG chapters (NYC and Hudson Valley) and events (Android Camp, DevFest NYC). Currently interested in machine learning, internet of things and ubiquitous computing technology.
nnarasimhan.name: Nitya Narasimhan

mperlak.bio:
My name is Mateusz (Mat) , I work for ContextMedia Health as senior software developer in android .My twelve years experience in the field range form image processing, backend high scalable server code to android and web front ends..
Currently, my team focus on educational platform for health care patients at point of care.
mperlak.name: Mateusz Perlak

mpotter.bio: I am an Android engineer working at Pinterest.  I focus on accessibility and app performance.  In my free time, I sing a capella and play soccer.
mpotter.name: Mallika Potter

yprabhu.bio:
Yash Prabhu leads the Android team at DramaFever (a Warner Bros. company). She has spoken at several tech meetups and conferences over the past three years. In her spare time, she volunteers at Google Developers Group/Android Alliance Philadelphia as a teaching assistant, instructor, mentor and organizer

Jessica’s career began nearly a decade ago at Condé Nast and Firstborn, before joining Radical.Media as a multi-disciplinary designer focusing on film, packaging, digital & print.  From there, her career focused in ecommerce as a lead designer at Born Group. Throughout her career she has been able to work with brands including Grey Goose,Tommy Hilfiger, Bon Jovi, Sandro (US), Movado, Red Bull, Phaidon and Tag Heuer.  

In recent years, Jessica has tackled Product Design at a DramaFever, Warner Bros. owned video streaming service, catering to millions of viewers worldwide. She is continually honing and developing her craft through different mediums of digital design, staying atop her field.
yprabhu.name: Yash  Prabhu

nroard.bio: Nicolas worked over the years on various projects at Google, from the HTML5 support in Android Browser, implementing the webview hardware acceleration in Honeycomb, or writing a scalable and non-destructive photo editor in JB/KitKat. After a year building high-speed telemetry systems for robots, he came back to Android, developed ConstraintLayout and now works on the Android Studio layout editor.
nroard.name: Nicolas Roard

pshadlyn.bio:
I love Android even more than baseball.

I'm an Android development for VarageSale, a family-friendly app which lets you buy and sell new and used items locally.  I’m also the lead Android developer for Triplify, an Australian-based startup which tells you what’s going on wherever you are. In a past life I was a controls engineer, but I started working with Android during the Froyo days and have never looked back.

I've presented at a number of Android meetups and tech events, including giving a talk on Android Auto at the Square offices in Kitchener, Ontario, Canada.  

Here are some of my previous presentations:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GeSKaz6PCm4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WNaJlP36I4E
https://speakerdeck.com/physphil
pshadlyn.name: Phil Shadlyn

bsills.bio: I am a Chicago-based Android developer working for Isobar, a digital marketing agency. Over the past few years, I've worked many projects for various clients, ranging from sports teams to fast food companies. I have presented a few small talks at local Android meetups. Outside of coding, I enjoy biking around the city, watching movies at my local theater, and going to concerts.
bsills.name: Bryan Sills

dsmith.bio:
Dave Smith is a Developer Advocate for IoT at Google, focused on growing
developer support on the Android Things platform. Dave has been
working with the Android stack at all levels since 2009, developing
custom applications and system components to run Android on
embedded platforms or interact with external embedded
devices. He has a passion for making things smart, whether that be other
developers or devices.
dsmith.name: Dave Smith

dstevenson.bio: Doug is a Google Developer Advocate working with the Firebase team.  He's been doing Android development since 2008 with the release of the first Android device, the HTC G1.  Outside of work, Doug follows NHL hockey and enjoys craft beer.
dstevenson.name: Doug Stevenson

hvisser.bio: Hugo is a software engineer who has worked on enterprise, desktop and mobile software products. Since the introduction of Android he has been steadily focussing on developing for Android only, resulting in his first app in 2009. Hugo has released several open source libraries and tools to help him and other developers build better software. He’s a Google Developer Expert for Android and one of the organizers of the Dutch Android User Group. With his company Little Robots, he focuses on smart use of Android in every possible way.
hvisser.name: Hugo  Visser

jwilson.bio: Jesse works on Square Cash in Waterloo Canada. He's contributed to OkHttp, Retrofit, Dagger, and Guava.
jwilson.name: Jesse Wilson
